When the Lights Go Out (Again)

Look, we both know why you're here. Another apagón hit, your family group chat exploded with voice notes, and now you're frantically Googling "best power station for Cuba" at 2am. Been there. The grid situation isn't getting better anytime soon, and sending cash for candles isn't cutting it anymore. These portable power stations can keep phones charged, fans running, and that precious mini fridge humming through 8-12 hour blackouts. The catch? Not every "camping generator" survives Cuban humidity, customs scrutiny, or the reality of being the only power source for an entire household. Let's find one that actually works.

Here's what nobody tells you about power stations for Cuba: wattage matters less than you think, and battery chemistry matters way more. Those cheap lithium-ion units from random Amazon sellers? They'll puff up like a tostón in Havana's humidity within 18 months. LiFePO4 (lithium iron phosphate) batteries handle heat and humidity dramatically better—we're talking 3,000+ charge cycles versus maybe 500 for standard lithium.

Weight is your other enemy. Anything over 25 pounds starts triggering extra shipping fees and suspicious customs looks. And forget solar panels for now unless you're sending separately—they add bulk, fragility, and complications. Focus on the station itself; solar can come later.

The real question isn't "how many watts?" It's "what actually needs to stay on?" A fan, phone chargers, LED lights, maybe a small TV—that's 200-400 watts. A full-size refrigerator? You're looking at 800W+ surge power. Know the household before you buy.

The Short Version

For most Cuban households dealing with regular apagones, the Jackery Explorer 1000 v2 hits the sweet spot—LiFePO4 battery that won't die in humidity, enough juice for 8+ hours of essentials, and a brand with actual warranty support. It's expensive ($$$$$), but it's the one you won't regret in two years.

Jackery Explorer 1000 v2

4.7★ 1070Wh • LiFePO4 • 1500W Output $$$$$

This is the one your family will still be using in 2030. The LiFePO4 battery chemistry is specifically built for hot, humid environments—exactly what destroys cheaper units. 1070Wh means running a fan, charging phones, and keeping LED lights on for a solid 10-12 hours. The 1500W output handles mini fridges during startup surge (something smaller units choke on). One-hour fast charging means they can top it up during those brief windows when power returns.

VERDICT: The "buy once, cry once" option. Worth every penny for households with daily apagones.

Need More Power? The 300W Class

These units step up to 300W continuous output—enough for small appliances, CPAP machines, or running multiple fans simultaneously. Heavier and pricier, but significantly more versatile.

For Medical Needs

EnginStar 300W (296Wh)

4.3★ 80000mAh • Pure Sine Wave $$$$$

Specifically marketed for CPAP users—and that pure sine wave output matters. Cheap "modified sine wave" units can damage sensitive medical equipment. If someone in the household uses a CPAP, nebulizer, or oxygen concentrator, this is the one. 296Wh runs a CPAP for 2-3 full nights.

VERDICT: The medical-grade option. Non-negotiable if health equipment is involved.

The Ultra-Budget Option

Sometimes you just need something—anything—that works. This is the "better than candles" tier.

Budget Pick

HOWEASY 120W (88Wh)

4.4★ 240W Peak • Built-in LED $$$

Let's be honest: 88Wh won't power much. You're looking at maybe 4-5 phone charges or running a small USB fan for a few hours. But it's light, it's cheap, and it has a built-in LED flashlight. For someone living alone who just needs phone power and light during blackouts, this gets the job done. Just don't expect miracles—and that standard lithium battery won't love Cuban humidity long-term.

VERDICT: Emergency backup only. Better than nothing, but plan to replace it in 2 years.

Side-by-Side Comparison

Still deciding? Here's how they stack up on the specs that actually matter for Cuba.

What Will Shipping Actually Cost?

Weight is the killer here. The Jackery is worth it, but shipping a 25-pound unit to Havana isn't cheap. Run the numbers before you commit.

Before You Ship: Quick Tips

  • ✓ Include a wall charger — Some units don't include one. Send a quality 65W+ USB-C charger separately.
  • ✓ Label it clearly — "Emergency Power Supply" on the customs form. Avoid "generator" language.
  • ✓ Send instructions in Spanish — Print out basic operation steps. YouTube tutorials won't load during blackouts.
  • ⚠ Skip the solar panels — Ship separately if needed. Combined packages get flagged and delayed.
  • ⚠ Charge it first — Ship at 50-60% charge. Fully depleted or fully charged batteries can be damaged in transit.

The Bottom Line

If you can afford it, send the Jackery Explorer 1000 v2. The LiFePO4 battery will outlast everything else on this list in Cuban conditions, and 1070Wh actually keeps a household functional during those 8-12 hour apagones. It's an investment, not an expense.

On a tighter budget? The GRECELL 240W LiFePO4 ($$$) gives you the humidity-resistant battery chemistry in a package that won't break the bank or your shipping budget. It won't run a fridge, but it'll keep phones charged and fans spinning—which is what most people actually need.
